{{ infobox football tournament | current = | logo = | caption = | founded = 2010 | number of teams = 2 | region = {{flagcountry|Belarus}} | current champions = [[FC Dinamo Brest|Dinamo Brest]] | most successful club = [[FC BATE Borisov|BATE Borisov]]
(7 titles) | broadcasters = | website = }} The '''Belarusian [[Super Cup]]''' is an annual one-match [[association football]] competition in Belarus organized by the [[Football Federation of Belarus]]. This competition serves as the season opener and is played between the [[Belarusian Premier League]] Champions and the [[Belarusian Cup]] Winners of the previous season. If a single team holds both titles, the Cup runners-up are invited. The match usually played in late February or early March each year. ==History== The predecessor to Belarusian Super Cup - the semi-official competition named Season Cup was contested in July 1994 between then-current champions and Cup holders [[FC Dinamo Minsk|Dinamo Minsk]] and Cup runners-up [[FC Bobruisk|Fandok Bobruisk]]. Dinamo won the match 5–3. The tournament was scrapped after just one edition.{{cite web |url=http://www.pressball.by/articles/football/belaruscup/65480 |title=Supercup 2010 preview |date=2010-03-04 |publisher=pressball.by}} The official Belarusian Super Cup competition was introduced in 2010 and is held every year since.{{cite web |url=http://www1.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=1459483.html |title=BATE clinch Belarusian Super Cup |date=2010-03-08 |publisher=uefa.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717135530/http://www1.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid%3D1459483.html |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }} Due to climate restrictions, it is usually played in enclosed [[Football Manege (Minsk)|Football Manege]] in Minsk. ==Matches== {| class="wikitable" |- !width=50|Year {{About|the football stadium|the residential district|Gosforth}} {{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox venue | name = Brunton Park | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = [[Image:Brunton Park Welcome.jpg|250px]] | caption = Main Stand | fullname = Brunton Park | former_names = | location = Warwick Road, [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]] | coordinates = {{Coord|54.89556|-2.91365|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = 1909 | opened = 2 September 1909, Carlisle United - [[Newcastle United FC|Newcastle United]]{{cite news |title=100 Years at Brunton Park |url=http://www.carlisleunited.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10361~1550857,00.html |publisher=Carlisle United |date=20 February 2009 |accessdate=25 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091101225754/http://www.carlisleunited.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10361~1550857%2C00.html |archivedate=1 November 2009 |df=dmy-all }} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Carlisle United FC|Carlisle United]] | operator = Carlisle United | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 17,949{{Cite web |url=http://www.carlisleunited.co.uk/documents/groundguide2016104-3210656.pdf# |title=Archived copy |access-date=15 May 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170517104559/http://www.carlisleunited.co.uk/documents/groundguide2016104-3210656.pdf# |archive-date=17 May 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} | suites = | record_attendance = 27,500 (Carlisle United - [[Birmingham City]], 5 January 1957, FA Cup 3rd Round) | dimensions = 112 x 74 yards | acreage = | tenants = | website = }} '''Brunton Park''' is a [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] and the home of [[Carlisle United FC]]. It is situated in the city of [[Carlisle, Cumbria|Carlisle]], [[Cumbria]] and has a certified capacity for the 2011/12 season of 18,202. The ground opened in 1909. Brunton Park's grandstand burned down in 1953 and the stadium flooded completely in 2005 and again in 2015. Brunton Park is split into four separate stands; Warwick Road End, East Stand, Main (West) Stand and the Petteril End, which remains closed unless exceptionally large crowds are in attendance. Brunton Park is the [[List of English football stadia by capacity|largest football stadium in England]] which is not all-seated. Carlisle United plan to move away from Brunton Park in the near future to a 12,000 capacity all-seater stadium. Before the 2012/13 season Cumbria County Council inspected Brunton Park and they deemed that certain areas of the stadium were unsafe. As a result, they reduced the capacity to 17,001 for the forthcoming season. == History == In 1904 Shaddongate United became Carlisle United F.C., an association football club who played at the Millholme Bank ground to the west of Carlisle. The ground was often too small for their purposes and they sometimes used the Rugby Ground which would later be the adjacent neighbour of Brunton Park. In 1905 United joined the Lancashire Combination league and required larger facilities so moved to Devonshire Park, a football ground which stood where [[Trinity School (Carlisle)|Trinity School]] now sits. In 1909 they were evicted from premises by the Duke of Devonshire and moved eastwards to establish Brunton Park, the club's home ever since.{{cite web |url= http://thebeautifulhistory.wordpress.com/clubs/carlisle-united/ |title=Carlisle United - The Beautiful History |accessdate=25 April 2011}} ===Grandstand fire=== In 1953 the original wooden grandstand which sat where the Main Stand now sits was burned to the ground in a fire cause by an electrical fault. The sale of local player [[Geoff Twentyman]] to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] for £12,500 enabled the club to rebuild the stadium into what is the West Stand today.{{cite web |url= http://www.united-trust.org.uk/newsletters/05.pdf |title=Tribute to Geoff Twentyman | publisher= Carlisle and Cumbria United In dependant Supporters Trust |accessdate=25 April 2011}} ===Flooding=== ;2005 On the evening of Friday 7 January 2005, the rivers Eden, Caldew and Petteril burst their banks in Carlisle due to as much as 180mm rainfall landing up stream that day.{{cite web |url= http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/climate/uk/interesting/jan2005floods/ |title=Carlisle Floods January 2005| publisher=Met office |accessdate=25 April 2011}} The worst affected area was Warwick Road, where Brunton Park is situated.http://www.bbc.co.uk/cumbria/content/images/2005/01/31/carlisleo_0123_470x353_470x354.jpg For the following six weeks Carlisle United were forced to play their home games at [[Christie Park (Morecambe, England)|Christie Park]] in [[Morecambe]] while repair work took place.{{cite web |url= http://www.cumberlandnews.co.uk/brunton-park-will-rock-as-united-return-after-month-long-flooding-nightmare-1.412552?referrerPath=2.935 |title= Brunton Park will rock as United return after month-long flooding nightmare |publisher= The Cumberland News |accessdate= 25 April 2011 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120309065120/http://www.cumberlandnews.co.uk/brunton-park-will-rock-as-united-return-after-month-long-flooding-nightmare-1.412552?referrerPath=2.935 |archivedate= 9 March 2012 |df= dmy-all }} United were still able, however, to reach the playoffs in the [[Conference National|Conference]] that season and win promotion back into [[the Football League]]. ;2015 The Stadium was severely flooded following [[Storm Desmond]]. It caused the team to play fixtures at Preston's [[Deepdale]] Ground, Blackburn's [[Ewood Park]] and Blackpool's [[Bloomfield Road]]. ;Other floods In November 2009 and November 2015, half the pitch and the match day car park were flooded but the stadium wasn't damaged. The match day car park is flooded a least once every year. == Layout == ===Paddock / Main (West) Stand=== [[File:Main Stand Carlisle Utd.jpg|thumb|Paddock/Main Stand]] The West Stand, is a 6,000 capacity mixed terraced and seated area. It is regarded as the main stand at Brunton Park and on average receives the highest attendance of home fans. The stand accommodates the club's offices and changing rooms as well as media facilities for radio and television coverage. The lower tier is mainly a paddock terrace which runs the length of the pitch. The home and away dugouts are situated in front of this stand with the tunnel dividing it through the centre. To the north is an area for disabled supporters The upper tier is known as the family stand with a small section to the south known as the 'A' Stand which houses school children. The full extent of the upper tier is seated and is the location of the stadium's most recent improvements, upgraded seating which was bought from [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] in 2006 during the club's move.{{cite web|url=http://www.fsf.org.uk/ground-guide/stadiums/carlisle/brunton-park-/|title=Brunton Park History|publisher=The FSF Ground Guide|accessdate=25 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101230194834/http://www.fsf.org.uk/ground-guide/stadiums/carlisle/brunton-park-/|archivedate=30 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} At the north end of the stand is also a viewing gallery positioned in-between the two tiers of the stand. The gallery sits in front of Foxy's restaurant which offers hospitality packages to supporters. ===Warwick Road End=== [[File:Warwick Road End.jpg|thumb|Warwick Road End]] The most distinctive of the four stands at Brunton Park, a unique covered terrace with a triple triangle roof, it is situated at the southern end of the stadium. Although currently called the 'Newcastle International Airport End' under a sponsorship deal, it is still affectionately known as 'the Warwick' to most Carlisle fans. The stand has a capacity of 3,500 and usually houses the most vocal supporters on match day. In the event low crowds are expected this stand can be closed to the public. ===East "Pioneer Foods" Stand=== Currently named the 'Pioneer Foods Stand', it is a 6,000 seater single-tiered cantilever stand. Although having been constructed a number of years ago, the club still have not completed the interior of the stand, thus the spaces at the top of the stand for executive boxes still stand empty. One peculiar thing fans may have noticed when visiting the ground is that the stand actually runs 20 yards past the goal line at the northern end of the pitch. This is because the club had erected the stand with a view of moving the pitch further northwards so a new stand at the southern end of the ground could also be built. These plans never materialised though, and the problem still stands today. The north section of the East Stand most commonly houses the away fans, separated from the home fans by nets and a gate in the concourse. When large groups of home fans are expected away fans are sometimes restricted to the Petteril End. In November 2010 local business and longtime supporters of the club the [[Stobart Group]] celebrated their 40th anniversary and bought 4,000 tickets on the East Stand for the [[League One]] fixture: Carlisle versus [[Rochdale A.F.C.|Rochdale]]. The company then gave away the tickets to the local public. On this occasion the away fans were moved solely to the Petteril End. ===Waterworks End=== [[File:Waterworks.jpg|thumb|Petteril End]] The Petteril is the only other uncovered stand in the ground alongside the lower tier paddock. The stand is a small capacity (2,000) terrace with a small seated area to the east. This stand usually remains closed unless exceptionally large crowds are expected. To the west of the stand is a small control tower which is used to facilitate crowd supervision on match days. Also located here is the only scoreboard in the stadium and an advertising screen which sometimes displays goal replays. ===Premier League pitch=== [[File:Cumberland Building Society Stand cropped.jpg|thumb|A view from the south east corner of Brunton Park towards the East Stand]] The [[Association football pitch|pitch]] at Brunton Park currently measures {{convert|104|by|67|m|yd|abbr=off}}. Originally a soil-based pitch was housed which was built over a landfill site; over the years this caused numerous settlement problems such as dips and crowns. When [[Bill Shankly]] joined the club in 1949 he called the ground "a glorified hen coop, everything was in terrible condition except for the pitch and that was always a good one".{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2386691/Carlisle-on-a-recovery-mission.html | title = Carlisle on a recovery mission | publisher = The Telegraph | accessdate =26 April 2011 | location=London | first=Ricky | last=George | date=14 September 2004 }} The pitch was and still is laid with local Solway turf, which is favoured by [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] and formerly [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley Stadium]] before its [[Wembley Stadium|renovation.]] The new Wembley Stadium was not laid with the turf and has since suffered multiple problems with its pitch.{{cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1267006/Wembley-confirm-new-pitch-laid-time-Mays-FA-Cup-final.html | title = Wembley pitch will be torn up and replaced in time for FA Cup final | publisher = Mail Online | accessdate =27 April 2011 | location=London | first=Simon | last=Cass | date=19 April 2010 }} During the flooding of January 2005, heavy deposits of silt were left on the playing field and a decision was made by the owners to build a new pitch and install a new primary drainage system.{{cite web |url= http://www.pitchcare.com/magazine/united-at-carlisle.html |title=United at Carlisle | publisher= Pitchcare.com |date=19 March 2008 |accessdate=25 April 2011}} ===Other areas=== [[File:Hughie McIlmoyle statue cropped.jpg|thumb|McIlmoyle statue outside Brunton Park]] The stadium has on-site parking to the east and north of the ground as well as a smaller parking area to the west. To the north of the ground is a separate pitch which is used for training purposes as well as reserve games. A club shop is situated south of the ground on Warwick Road. The shop was renovated before reopening after the flooding in 2005, turning over £20,000 on its first day back in business.{{cite web |url=http://www.cumberlandnews.co.uk/hughie-to-unveil-statue-at-united-open-day-1.369702?referrerPath=2.935 |title=Hughie to unveil statue at United open day |publisher=The Cumberland News |date=29 July 2005 |accessdate=25 April 2011 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In front of the shop stands a life-size bronze statue of former player [[Hugh McIlmoyle]]. ==Other uses== [[File:424px-BruntonParkPlan-en.png|thumb|A plan of Brunton Park. The shaded area indicates the section most commonly designated for away fans.]] In 1982, Brunton Park hosted a [[rugby league]] match between Cumbria and [[Australian Kangaroos|Australia]] during the Aussie's [[1982 Kangaroo tour]]. On their way to their first ever undefeated [[Kangaroo Tour|tour of Great Britain and France]], the Kangaroos, who would become known as "The Invincibles", defeated Cumbria 41-2 in front of just 5,748 fans. In 2007 Brunton Park was transformed into a 20,000 capacity concert venue to host [[Elton John]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cumberlandnews.co.uk/news/blues-army-for-elton-at-brunton-park-1.171356?referrerPath=home/2.3080|title=Blues army for Elton at Brunton Park|publisher=Cumberland News|date=8 June 2007|accessdate=25 April 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309065130/http://www.cumberlandnews.co.uk/news/blues-army-for-elton-at-brunton-park-1.171356?referrerPath=home%2F2.3080|archivedate=9 March 2012|df=dmy-all}} In 2010 Brunton Park was used during the production of the BBC television programme ''[[United (TV drama)|United]]'', a docudrama centring on [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] at the time of the [[Munich air disaster]]. The ground was chosen due to a likeness in parts of the stadium with 1950s [[Old Trafford]].{{cite web |url= http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/tv_and_showbiz/s/1417289_tv-drama-united-to-tell-story-of-busby-babes |title=TV drama ''United'' to tell story of Busby Babes| publisher=Manchester Evening News|first=Ian |last=Wylie |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=17 April 2011}} ==Records== Record attendance: (tied) 27,500 Carlisle United-[[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]], 5 January 1957, FA Cup 3rd Round
27,500 (Carlisle United-[[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], 7 February 1970, FA Cup 5th Round
Record gate receipts: £146,000 (Carlisle United-[[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], 30 September 1997, Coca-Cola Cup 2nd Round Brunton Park was the first ground to host an FA cup match between league clubs played under lights. Carlisle United played [[Darlington F.C.|Darlington]] in a first round replay, losing 1-3. ==Planned developments== By the time of the East Stand's opening in August 1996, plans were afoot to redevelop Brunton Park into a 28,000 capacity all-seater stadium. However, the club's lack of progress on the pitch over the next decade, along with the subsequent departure of ambitious owner [[Michael Knighton]], meant that the stadium remained unchanged from that date.{{cite web|url=http://www.kynson.splathosting.com/RIOA/club/history.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-11-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425232222/http://www.kynson.splathosting.com/RIOA/club/history.htm |archivedate=25 April 2012 |df=dmy }} On 18 November 2011, with Carlisle United F.C. established in League One (third tier) for the sixth season, the club announced plans to leave Brunton Park for a new 12,000-seat stadium in the Kingmoor area of the city. These plans come under the slogan 'Project Blue Yonder'.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15788028.stm | work=BBC News | title=Carlisle reveal ground move plans | date=18 November 2011}} ==Photo gallery== Image:Brunton Park Main Stand.jpg|Main Stand and Paddock Image:Brunton Park Petteril End cropped.jpg|Petteril End Image:Brunton Park Warwick Road End.jpg|Warwick Road End ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commonscat}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080317085354/http://www.carlisleunited.premiumtv.co.uk/page/TheStadium/0%2C%2C10361%2C00.html Brunton Park] Carlisle United F.C. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130620050843/http://pitchmap.co.uk/brunton-park.html Brunton Park] at PitchMap.co.uk {{Football League Two Venues}} [[Category:Carlisle United F.C.]] [[Category:Football venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues in Cumbria]] [[Category:Defunct rugby league venues in England]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1909]] [[Category:English Football League venues]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Carlisle, Cumbria]]

Right Field — 328 ft (100 m) }} The '''Chengcing Lake Baseball Stadium''' ({{zh|c=澄清湖棒球場|p=Chéngqīng Hú Bàngqiú Chǎng}}) is a [[baseball]] [[stadium]] located in [[Niaosong District]], [[Kaohsiung City]], [[Taiwan]], on the side of [[Chengcing Lake]]. The stadium opened in 1999 and has been the home of [[Kaohsiung-Pingtung Fala]] (1999–2002), [[First Financial Holdings Agan]] (2003), [[La New Bears]] (2004-2010), and [[EDA Rhinos]] (2013–present).{{cite web|url=http://www.stadiumjourney.com/stadiums/chengcing-lake-baseball-field-s1668/ |title=Chengcing Lake Baseball Field Reviews, EDA Rhinos |publisher=Stadium Journey |date= |accessdate=2014-05-25}} ==See also== {{commons category|Chengcing Lake Baseball Field}} * [[List of stadiums in Taiwan]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Baseball venues in Taiwan}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1999]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Taiwan]] [[Category:Sports venues in Kaohsiung]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Taiwan]] {{Taiwan-sports-venue-stub}} {{Asia-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | name = City Park Ice Rink
''Városligeti Műjégpálya'' | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Műjegpalyabp.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Aerial view of the skating rink | fullname = | former_names = | location = [[City Park (Budapest)|City Park]], [[Budapest]], [[Hungary]] | coordinates = {{Coord|47.5138969 |19.0801155|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = 1869 | opened = {{Start date|1870|1|29|df=y}} | renovated = 1968, 2011 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = City of Budapest | operator = | surface = Ice | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = 180x67 metres (bandy and skating rink)
60x30 metres (ice hockey rink) | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Budapesti Korcsolyázó Egylet]] ; [[Hungarian Bandy Federation]] | embedded = | website = [http://mujegpalya.hu Official website] }} {{Commons category|City Park Ice Rink}} {{Commons category|Skating Hall}} The '''City Park Ice Rink''' ({{lang-hu|Városligeti Műjégpálya}}) is a public ice rink located in the [[City Park (Budapest)|City Park]] of the Hungarian capital [[Budapest]], between the [[Hősök tere|Heroes' Square]] and the [[Vajdahunyad Castle]]. Opened in 1870, it is the largest{{cite web|url=http://www.budapest.com/budapest_city_park_(varosliget)/ice-skating_rink_and_lake.en.html|title=Ice-Skating Rink and Lake|publisher=budapest.com|accessdate=17 December 2011}} and one of the oldest ice rinks in Europe. In summer months the area is filled up with water to create a pond, which is primarily used for boating, but also hosted several special events, such as the snowball fight world record attempt in 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.saatchi.hu/en/news/archive/snowball_fight_world_record_attempt_on_the__t-home_and_t-mobile_family_day|title=Snowball Fight World Record Attempt on the T-Home and T-Mobile Family Day|publisher=Saatchi & Saatchi Hungary|date=2 February 2009|accessdate=17 December 2011}} or the Art on Lake exhibition in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.artonlake.hu/static.php?pmPage=exhibition|title=Contemporary art exhibition on boating lake at City Park Lake|publisher=artonlake.hu|accessdate=17 December 2011}} It went through a complete renovation between 2009 and 2011, in which the main building was restored to its 19th-century look. The skating area was expanded to {{convert|12,000|m2|sqft}} and a standard ice hockey rink was set up as well. The skating rink re-opened on 16 December 2011 and it was the home of the [[2012 European Speed Skating Championships]] from 6 to 8 January. The memorial of the [[Hungarian Ice Hockey Hall of Fame]] is also found at the City Park Ice Rink since its inauguration in February 2012.{{cite web|url=http://icehockey.hu/index.php?pg=news_13_3280 |title=A Városligeti Műjégen lesz látható a magyar hoki legendáit bemutató kiállítás |publisher=Hungarian Ice Hockey Federation |date=21 February 2012 |accessdate=25 February 2012 |language=Hungarian |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510135156/http://icehockey.hu/index.php?pg=news_13_3280 |archivedate=10 May 2012 |df= }} ==History== In the second part of the nineteenth century the pleasant environment of the City Park became a beloved place for relaxation, entertainment and freetime activities. On the City Park Lake boating and rowing were popular sports to practice and during the winter skaters also appeared on the frozen lake. In the end of 1869, with the guidance of [[Géza Kresz]] the [[Budapesti Korcsolyázó Egylet|Pesti Korcsolyázó Egylet]] (Skating Association of Pest) was founded, and they also obtained the permission of the city council to create an ice rink on a part of the City Park Lake. A wooden pavilion was built on the shore of the lake as well, where the visitors could warm up and change their skates. The official opening ceremony took place on 29 January 1870 in the presence of [[Rudolf, Crown Prince of Austria]], and skating got underway immediately, with the first ever race held on 2 February.{{cite web|url=http://www.epulettar.hu/projekt/24989.aspx|title=Városligeti Műjégpálya, Budapest XIV.|publisher=Épülettár|accessdate=17 December 2011|language=Hungarian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130217193944/http://www.epulettar.hu/projekt/24989.aspx|archivedate=17 February 2013|df=}} This time the association had only 35 members, which increased to 432 by the end of the year.{{cite web|url=http://www.varosliget.info/mujegpalya.html|title=Műjégpálya|publisher=varosliget.info|accessdate=17 December 2011|language=Hungarian|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110911005521/http://www.varosliget.info/mujegpalya.html|archivedate=11 September 2011|df=}} The outset of figure skating in Hungary can be dated from 6 January 1871, when [[Jackson Haines]], who is regarded as the father of figure skating, presented his show for the Hungarian audience. He repeated his visit in the next year, due to that figure skating gained ground quickly among Hungarian skaters.{{cite web|url=http://www.moksz.hu/bemutatkozas.htm|title=A magyar korcsolyázósport története|trans-title=The history of the Hungarian skating sport|publisher=Hungarian National Skating Federation|accessdate=17 December 2011|language=Hungarian}} In 1874 the wooden cottage was burnt down, following that a new stable building was erected by the plans of Hungarian secessionist architect [[Ödön Lechner]]. On the ground floor was found the changing room and warming room, while on the upstaris was placed the main hall and the music room. For 1879 floodlights were installed to ensure a skating opportunity at nights. Budapesti Korcsolyázó Egylet, as Pesti Korcsolyázó Egylet was known since the unification of Buda, Pest and Óbuda in 1873, was one of the five founding members of the [[International Skating Union]] (ISU) in 1892 and it won the organization rights of the [[1895 European Figure Skating Championships]], which took place at the City Park Ice Rink. For 1893 due to the increasing number of the visitors the main building was proved to be too small and was replaced by a bigger [[Baroque Revival architecture|neo-baroque]] style building designed by [[Imre Francsek]]. Beside sport events the skating rink gave home of ice feasts and shows. The fortieth anniversary of the foundation of the Pesti Korcsolyázó Egylet in 1909 was celebrated with a costume festival, in which the coronation of [[Matthias I of Hungary]] was performed, that originally took place on the frozen Danube. The king was personated by Count Károly Andrássy. In the same year in the Városliget was held the [[1909 World Figure Skating Championships]], the first ever World event in Hungary, in which local skater [[Lily Kronberger]] triumphed.{{cite web|url=http://budapestcity.org/03-muemlekek/14/Jegpalya/index-hu.htm|title=Városligeti Műjégpálya|publisher=budapestcity.org|accessdate=17 December 2011|language=Hungarian}} Because of the World War I skating life experienced a setback, as skaters began to return to the City Park Ice Rink slowly at first, however, it speeded up after the articifal skate rink was handed over on 26 November 1926. The season grew for 105 days long, which offered more time for exercising and organizing competitions that gave a boost for the sport. [[File:Mujegpalya Ice Rink.jpg|thumb|250px|right|The skating rink with the [[Vajdahunyad Castle]] in the background]] In 1929 Budapest hosted the [[1929 World Figure Skating Championships|Figure Skating World Championship]] for ladies and pairs and in the 1930s Hungarian figure skaters won a number of European and World titles: the [[Olga Orgonista]]–[[Sándor Szalay (figure skater)|Sándor Szalay]] pair won the European Championship, while the [[Emilia Rotter]]–[[László Szollás]] duo won four World Championships between 1931 and 1935. The latter ones also won bronze medal both at the 1932 and 1936 Winter Olympics. By that time the seats of the grandstand was heated by electric plates. Prices were high, a seating place cost 5 [[Hungarian pengő|pengő]], from which one could buy a pair of shoes.{{cite web|url=http://varosliget.info/mujegpalya.html?start=1|title=Műjégpálya|publisher=varosliget.info|accessdate=17 December 2011|language=Hungarian}} During the World War II, in the 1944 bombings the rink suffered serious damages. After the end of the war works began to recostruct the skating rink and for the autumn of 1945 bigger part of it became serviceable again. Further expansions took place in the 1960s when the skating area was enlarged, and standard, 400 metres long speed skating tracks were adapted. It is the only ice surface for [[bandy]] in Hungary and the [[Bandy World Championship 2004|Bandy World Championship 2004, Group B]], was played here,[http://www.bandyvm.se/RTE/my_documents/my_pictures/VM_2004/budapest.jpg Photo from the match between the home team and Canada] as well as the [[Bandy World Championship for women 2007]]. Most recently the Városligeti Műjégpálya was renovated and expanded from 2009 to 2011. The total cost of the amelioration process was 4.7 billion [[Hungarian Forint]] (approximately €16 million), of which about €3 billion came from the [[European Regional Development Fund]]. After the redevelopment the skating area grew by 15 percent, and now it consist a 180×67 metres skating rink and an international standard ice hockey rink. The quality of the largest ice surface in Europe is ensured by the about {{convert|210|km|mi}} long embedded cooling tube system. The interior of the main building, which is a national monument, was restored to the 1926 state with its gilded pillars and banisters,{{cite web|url=http://www.hir24.hu/belfold/2011/12/13/kinyit-a-varosligeti-mujegpalya/|title=Kinyit a Városligeti Műjégpálya|publisher=hir24.hu|date=13 December 2011|accessdate=17 December 2011|language=Hungarian}} and went through further expansions: a culture and tourism center, and an event hall was established inside the building, which make enable it to host conferences and to offer other activities (exhibitions, cultural programs) beside skating and boating.{{cite web|url=http://www.nfu.hu/content/3349|title=2010 végéig megújul a Városligeti Műjégpálya|publisher=National Development Agency|date=24 June 2009|accessdate=17 December 2011|language=Hungarian}} ==Events== The following major international events took place at the skating rink: * [[1895 European Figure Skating Championships]] * 1895 European Speed Skating Championships * 1909 European Speed Skating Championships * [[Ice Hockey European Championship 1929|1929 Ice Hockey European Championship]] * [[1929 World Figure Skating Championships]] (ladies and pairs) * [[1935 World Figure Skating Championships]] (men and pairs) * [[1939 World Figure Skating Championships]] (men and pairs) * [[1955 European Figure Skating Championships]] * [[1963 European Figure Skating Championships]] * [[2001 World Allround Speed Skating Championships]] * [[Bandy World Championship 2004|2004 Bandy World Championship, Group B]] * [[Bandy World Championship for women 2007|2007 Women's Bandy World Championships]] * [[2012 European Speed Skating Championships]] ==Track records== These are the track records of the City Park Ice Rink as of 8 January 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.speedskatingnews.info/?page_id=826&bahn=UNBU|title=Rink card of Városligeti Műjégpálya Budapest|publisher=Speed Skating News|accessdate=9 January 2012}} {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="5" | Men |- ! Distance ! Time ! Skater ! Date set ! Duration |- | 100 m | 11.66 | {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Róbert Erdei]] | 17 January 1998 | {{age in days|1998|1|17}} days |- | 500 m | 36.89 | {{flagicon|POL}} [[Konrad Niedźwiedzki]] | 6 January 2012 | {{age in days|2012|1|6}} days |- | 1,000 m | 1:16.02 | {{flagicon|HUN}} [[Zsolt Baló]] | 27 January 2001 | {{age in days|2001|1|27}} days |- | 1,500 m | 1:53.98 | {{flagicon|NED}} [[Sven Kramer]] | 7 January 2012 | {{age in days|2012|1|7}} days |- | 3,000 m | 4:06.73 | {{flagicon|NED}} [[Kees de Ruyter]] | 12 February 2000 | {{age in days|2000|2|12}} days |- | 5,000 m | 6:31.82 | {{flagicon|NED}} [[Sven Kramer]] | 6 January 2012 | {{age in days|2012|1|6}} days |- | 10,000 m | 13:44.19 | {{flagicon|NED}} [[Bart Veldkamp]] | 10 February 2001 | {{age in days|2001|2|10}} days |} {{col-2}} {| class="wikitable" ! colspan="5" | Women |- ! {{notability|Sport|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Anglo | image = [[File:Club Atlético Anglo logo.png|150px]] | fullname = Club Atlético Anglo | nickname = ''Albirrojos'' | founded = June 1, 1907| | ground = [[Parque Anglo]]
[[Fray Bentos]], [[Uruguay]]| capacity = 1,800 | chairman = Raúl Doti | manager = ? | league = [[Liga Departamental de Fútbol de Río Negro]]| season = | position = | website = http://clubanglo.com.uy | }} '''Club Atlético Anglo''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] club from [[Fray Bentos]] in [[Uruguay]]. Established on June 1, 1907 with the denomination Liebig Football Club, changed later. On June 13, 1912, together with the [[Fray Bentos F.C.]] was established the [[Liga Departamental de Fútbol de Río Negro]].[http://www.futboldelinterior.com/guia/liga-fraybentos.html Liga Departamental de Fútbol de Río Negro (Fray Bentos)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018065448/http://www.futboldelinterior.com/guia/liga-fraybentos.html |date=2011-10-18 }} The "Anglo" is notable for its secular rivalry with the [[Laureles F.C.]].[http://www.laurelesfc.com.uy/SabiaUd/clasicoAnglo.html One of the oldest football derbies in the world] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303212712/http://www.laurelesfc.com.uy/SabiaUd/clasicoAnglo.html |date=2016-03-03 }} (in Spanish) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://clubanglo.com.uy/?page_id=12 First Division] * [http://estadiosdeuruguay.blogspot.com/2011/05/club-atletico-anglo.html Parque Anglo] {{DEFAULTSORT:Anglo, Club Atletico}} [[Category:Football clubs in Uruguay]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1907]] [[Category:1907 establishments in Uruguay]] [[Category:Fray Bentos]] {{Uruguay-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|pitch count}} {{refimprove|date=January 2008}} In [[baseball]] and [[softball]], the '''count''' refers to the number of [[Strike zone|balls and strikes]] a batter has in his current [[plate appearance]]. It is usually announced as a pair of numbers, for example, 3-1 (pronounced as "three and one," or, alternatively, "a three-one count"), with the first number being the number of [[Base on balls|balls]] and the second being the number of [[Strike (baseball)|strikes]]. An individual [[Pitch (baseball)|pitch]] may also be referred to by the count prior to its delivery, for example, a pitch thrown with a count of three balls and one strike would be called a "three-one pitch." A count of 1-1 or 2-2 is called '''even'''. Zero is commonly pronounced "oh," although a 0-0 count is rarely expressed as such — the count is typically not mentioned until at least one pitch has been thrown.
==About== The home plate [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]] will signal the count with the number of balls on his left hand, and the number of strikes on his right hand. (As a result, it reads backwards when viewed from the pitcher's point of view.) Individual umpires vary in how frequently they give this signal; it is often done as a reminder when there has been a slight delay between pitches (such as the batter stepping out of the [[batter's box]]). It can also be a signal to the [[scoreboard]] operator that an incorrect count is being shown on the board. Some umpires may also give the count verbally, although usually only the batter and the [[catcher]] can hear it.
An important part of [[baseball statistics]] is measuring which counts are most likely to produce favorable outcomes for the [[pitcher]] or the hitter. Counts of 3-1 and 2-0 are considered hitters' counts, because the pitcher—faced with the possibility of [[base on balls|walking]] the batter—is more likely to throw a ball in the [[strike zone]], particularly a [[fastball]]. Somewhat surprisingly, in general, a 3-0 count tends to yield fewer hittable pitches, depending on the situation. (Baseball fans have often suggested that this is because umpires are reluctant to call four straight balls and as a result "ease up" on the fourth pitch, treating it as having a wider strike zone.) Often batters will '''take''' (not swing at) a 3-0 pitch, since the pitcher has missed the strike zone three straight times already, and a fourth would earn the batter a walk. This is a sound strategy because the batter is more likely to eventually reach base even if the count becomes 3-1 than he is if he puts the ball in play on 3-0.<ref>Bickel, J. Eric. 2009. On the decision to take a pitch. Decision Anal. 6(3) 186-193.</ref> In some situations, it is also advantageous to take on 2-0 and 3-1.<ref>Bickel, J. E. 2009. On the decision to take a pitch. Decision Anal. 6(3) 186-193.</ref>
Counts with two strikes (except 3-2) are considered pitchers' counts. An 0-2 count is very favorable to a pitcher. In such a count, the pitcher has the freedom to throw one (or sometimes two) pitches out of the strike zone intentionally, in an attempt to get the batter to '''chase''' the pitch (swing at it), and [[strikeout|strike out]]. Arguing as to whether a pitch was a ball or a strike (which is a judgment call by the umpire) is strictly prohibited by [[Major League Baseball]] rules. Such an infringement, known as "arguing balls and strikes," will quickly lead to a warning from the umpire, and the player or [[manager (baseball)|manager]] may be ejected from the game if they continue to argue.<ref>http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/official_info/official_rules/umpire_9.jsp</ref>
==Full count== A '''full count''' (sometimes called a '''full house''', which is the usual term in [[softball]]) is the common name for a count where the [[batter (baseball)|batter]] has three balls and two [[strike zone|strikes]]. The term may derive from older [[scoreboard]]s, which had three spaces for balls and two for strikes, since this is the maximum number of each that can be achieved before the plate appearance ends (such as with a [[strikeout]], walk or hit). Many scoreboards still use light bulbs for this purpose, and thus a 3-2 count means all the bulbs are fully lit up. The alternative or variant term ''full house'' is likely to have been influenced by the [[poker]] term for a hand with three of a kind and a pair.
Another strike against the batter will result in a [[strikeout]], while another ball will result in a [[base on balls|walk]]. However, a batter may maintain the two strikes indefinitely by hitting [[foul ball]]s, so a full count does not always mean that only five pitches have been thrown, nor that there is only one more pitch to throw.
A [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]] which is thrown with a full count is often referred to as a "payoff pitch", since it is likely to be a good pitch for the batter to swing at. With three balls already, the pitcher cannot afford to miss the [[strike zone]], which would result in ball four and a walk for the batter.
Baserunners often will run on the pitch, even if they are not very fast runners, especially with two outs, as runners cannot be caught stealing or doubled off because the batter either will strike out to end the inning, walk to force the runners to advance, or put the ball in play and an out would be the third in an inning (in the event of a foul ball, the runner must return to his original base).
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox Figure Skating Element |image= Death-Spiral Figure-Skating.png |imagesize= |caption= |element name= Death spiral |alt name= |scoring abbrev= Ds |element type= |edges= |take off edge= |landing edge= |inventor= |named for= |disciplines= [[Pair skating]] }}
'''Death spiral''' is a required element of [[pair skating]] performed with the man in a [[Glossary_of_figure_skating_terms#P|pivot]] position, one toe anchored in the [[ice]]. Holding his hand, the woman circles her partner on a deep edge with her body almost parallel to the ice. In 2011, the ISU introduced a requirement that the woman's head must at some time reach the level of her skating knee in order to receive a value.<ref name=isu121001/> The man should be in a full pivot position, and the death spiral must be held for a minimum amount of rotation, depending on the level.
==Variations== [[Image:McLaughlin Brubaker Death Spiral.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Back inside death spiral]] [[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-N0111-0030, Romy Kermer, Rolf Oesterreich.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Back outside death spiral]] [[Image:Siudek & Siudek Death Spiral - 2006 Skate America.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Forward inside death spiral]] [[Image:Rus-nat-tt-mm3.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Woman in shoot-the-duck position during entry to back inside death spiral]] [[Image:Aliona Savchenko & Robin Szolkowy Death Spiral 2009 Europeans.jpg|right|thumb|150px|Man in difficult catch-foot position during entry to forward inside death spiral]] [[Image:WC 2010 Tong Jian and Pang Qing (death spiral).jpg|right|thumb|150px|Woman in catch-foot position during back outside death spiral]]
Death spirals can be performed in all four variants of inside/outside and forward/backward edges. The outside edge death spirals are considered more difficult than the inside edge variants. The forward outside death spiral is seen as the hardest of all.
Pairs may increase their score by incorporating a difficult entry or exit and/or holding the position during the death spiral. These may be one of the [[Figure skating spiral|spiral positions]], the [[Biellmann spin|Biellmann]], [[List of figure skating terms|shoot-the-duck]], or other position. Pairs may also change the hand hold during the death spiral.
==History== The backward outside death spiral was invented in 1928 by [[Charlotte Oelschlagel]] and [[Curt Neumann]],<ref>Kelli Lawrence, [https://books.google.com/books?id=7qSiLyFZy1YC&pg=PA9&lpg=PA9&dq=%22death+spiral%22+skating+%22Charlotte+Oelschlagel%22&source=bl&ots=Xp_ly_hZfo&sig=Ft-EYsengomcxAw8miFYRm13f4k&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0qjgUfiSG4nj4APGwIDgDQ&ved=0CDwQ6AEwAw ''Skating on Air: The Broadcast History of an Olympic Marquee Sport''], p. 8</ref> although it was first performed with the skaters holding both hands and the woman not fully lowered toward the ice.{{fact|date=July 2013|reason= the date was until this edit off by abt 25 years, & the Kelli Lawrence source does not hint that, and note the earlier Charlotte spiral (see that article) is NOT a death spiral.}} The current{{vague|date=July 2013|"current" seems to imply two-hands is obsolete, yet we have a 2-handed photo. Did the contributor perhaps mean that 2-handed is worthless in some or all competitions? A ref is almost always appropriate}} one-handed version was developed in the 1940s by the Canadian pair [[Suzanne Morrow]] and [[Wallace Diestelmeyer]]. The other death spiral variants were invented by [[Ludmila Belousova]] and [[Oleg Protopopov]] in the 1960s.<ref name=poiLBOP/> They assigned the following names to them: ''Cosmic spiral'' (backward inside), ''Life spiral'' (forward inside), and ''Love spiral'' (forward outside).
==ISU Judging System== Under the [[ISU Judging System]], the death spiral is abbreviated as "Ds" in the protocol, and preceded by a capital F or B indicating the direction and lower-case i or o for the edge; the level appears as a digit following the four letters.<ref name=isu1445/> Thus the abbreviations are:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Edge ! Abbreviation |- | Forward Inside | FiDs |- | Forward Outside | FoDs |- | Backward Inside | BiDs |- | Backward Outside | BoDs |}
A level three backward inside death spiral would be written as ''BiDs3''.
For the 2007-2008 season, the back inside death spiral was the required death spiral for the senior pairs [[short program (figure skating)|short program]]. For the 2008-2009 season, the required death spiral was the forward inside.<ref name=isusr06/>
==References== {{Reflist|refs=
<ref name=poiLBOP>{{Citation | url = http://www.pairsonice.net/profileview.php?pid=99 | title = Lyudmila Belousova & Oleg Protopopov | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100107032008/http://www.pairsonice.net/profileview.php?pid=99 | archivedate = 7 January 2010 | deadurl = yes }}</ref>
<ref name=isu121001>{{cite web |url=http://www.isu.org/vsite/vfile/page/fileurl/0,11040,4844-206269-223492-177589-0-file,00.pdf |format=PDF |title=2012/2013 Records of Clarifications from Sports Directorate and Technical Committee: PAIR SKATING Death Spirals |work=International Skating Union |date=1 October 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DUb1sCmt?url=http://www.isu.org/vsite/vfile/page/fileurl/0%2C11040%2C4844-206269-223492-177589-0-file%2C00.pdf |archivedate=7 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
<ref name=isu1445>{{cite web | url = http://www.isu.org/vsite/vfile/page/fileurl/0,11040,4844-183415-200633-121139-0-file,00.pdf | format = PDF | title = Communication No. 1445 | work = International Skating Union | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070707032658/http://www.isu.org/vsite/vfile/page/fileurl/0%2C11040%2C4844-183415-200633-121139-0-file%2C00.pdf | archivedate = 7 July 2007 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref>
<ref name=isusr06>{{cite web | url = http://www.isu.org/vsite/vfile/page/fileurl/0,11040,4844-206192-223415-177357-0-file,00.pdf | title = Special Regulations & Technical Rules: Single & Pair Skating and Ice Dance 2012 | work = International Skating Union | format = PDF | date = June 2012 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20131029201118/http://www.isu.org/vsite/vfile/page/fileurl/0%2C11040%2C4844-206192-223415-177357-0-file%2C00.pdf | archivedate = 29 October 2013 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref>
}}

(600,000 Euros, in 2000) | former names = Estádio Adidas | capacity = 2500 | suites = 25 | tenants = [[Baxada]]
Desportivo de Cova Figueira
Esperança (Achada Furna)
Figueira Pavão
Parque Real }} The '''Estádio Monte Pelado''', rarely known as '''Estádio Monte Pe Largo''' is a stadium in [[Cova Figueira]], [[Cape Verde]] not far from the small mountain named Monte Pelado. South of the stadium is Ribeira do Coxo. The stadium is owned by the municipality of Santa Catarina do Fogo and is operated by the [[Fogo Regional Football Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fcf.cv/pt/index.php/associacoes/fogo |title=Fogo Regional Football Association |publisher=Fcf.cv |date= |accessdate=2017-11-19}} ==Description== The stadium was built in May 1999 and opened its doors in July 2000, construction cost CV$55 million ($US 550,000, 600,000 Euros, 2000 value) and had a capacity of 1,000 and the field size of 100 x 60 m. It is the home of several minor clubs including [[Baxada]] and Desportivo de Cova Figueira. It is also the home field of Esperança, a club based in nearby [[Achada Furna]] and the newly registered Figueira Pavão club based southwest of the stadium. Desportivo Cova Figueira, as they are in the [[Fogo Second Division|Second Division]] continue to play its matches at the stadium. Clubs based in the stadium and participating in the Second Division continues to play at the stadium. The stadium was renovated in 2008, it's more new and has more touching models in it that represents each team. The City Hall of Cova Figueira planned to expand it. Recently around late 2015, the stadium underwent renovations as to that of São Lourenço as well as some expansions including its seats, its field became artificial turf and it was competed on November 18, 2017, its works costs CV$32 million, seating capacity added to 2,500 and its field size became 100 x 64 meters.{{cite news|url=http://www.asemana.publ.cv/?Campo-de-futebol-de-Santa-Catarina-no-Fogo-pronto-em-Novembro&ak=1|title=Campo de futebol de Santa Catarina no Fogo pronto em Novembro|trans-title=Football Field for Santa Catarina do Fogo Starts in November|newspaper=A Semana|language=pt|date=October 15, 2017|accessdate=2017-11-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fogonews.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2794:fogo-est%C3%A1dio-municipal-santa-catarina-do-fogo-baptizado-com-o-nome-de-monte-pel&catid=2:video-noticias&Itemid=3|title=Fogo: Estádio Municipal Santa Catarina do Fogo baptizado com o nome de Monte Pelado|newspaper=Fogo News|date=20 November 2017|accessdate=2017-11-20}} For the 2017-18 season, its matches features the Eastern Group clubs that are based in the municipality, one of two, the other is [[Estádio Francisco José Rodrigues]] in Mosteiros. ==See also== *[[List of football stadiums in Cape Verde]] *[[List of buildings and structures in Fogo, Cape Verde]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Fogo Island League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Monte Pelado Estadio}} [[Category:Football venues in Cape Verde]] [[Category:Santa Catarina do Fogo]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2000]] {{CapeVerde-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Refimprove|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = MOL Aréna | image = [[File:Dacarena.png|250px]] | caption = '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA]]''' [[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]][[File:Nuvola apps mozilla.png|12px]] | location = Športová ulica 18 [[Dunajská Streda]], [[Slovakia]] | coordinates = {{Coord|47|59|56|N|17|37|6|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | dimensions = 105 x 68 m | opened = 1953 | renovated = 2015–present | closed = | demolished = | owner = DAC Aréna, a.s. | operator = [[DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda]] | surface = Grass | construction_cost = €22 million (2015–2017) | architect = Csaba Ambrus (ADIF) | former_names = Mestský štadión (1953–2016)
DAC Aréna (2016–2017)
MOL Aréna (2017–present) | tenants = [[DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda]] | capacity = 10,352 (under renovation) http://fcdac.sk/hu/hirek/2018/07/24/mennyi-a-mol-arena-jelenlegi-befogadokepessege | record_attendance = {{formatnum: 15572}} ([[FC DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda|D.Streda]] vs [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]], 1988) | website = [http://fcdac.sk/sk/historia-klubu www.fcdac.sk] }} '''MOL Aréna''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Dunajská Streda]], [[Slovakia]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home ground of [[DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda]]. The stadium holds currently 10,352 people (under renovation). The intensity of the floodlighting is 1,800 lux. ==History== Stadium was opened in 1953. The main stand was built in the first half of the 1980s and was inaugurated for the 1985 [[Spartakiad]]. Capacity was 16,410 spectators. The stadium underwent reconstruction in 2008, when [[DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda]] started play in [[Corgoň Liga]] by merging with [[FC Senec]]. In the 2016-17 league season, DAC drew an average home attendance of 4,112http://www.european-football-statistics.co.uk/attn.htm, the highest in the league. == 2016-2018 reconstruction == Between 2016 and 2018, the current stadium will be replaced by a new, modern, all-sitting arena with capacity of 12,700 spectators. In spring 2016 the old stands (except the main stand) were demolished. In June 2016, the construction of the new stadium began. In the first phase two new stands were built with an edge-stand between them. The main construction works finished in September. In November the stadium was ready for Slovakia league matches. In the next phase will be constructed the main stand with dressing rooms, VIP and press rooms, fanshop, club museum and restaurant. At least, there will be constructed the last stand which will replace current main stage. In this phase the facade of the stadium will be also constructed. The new arena will have 4-star UEFA standard so it can be used for international matches.{{Cite web|url=http://fcdac.sk/sk/spravy/2016/04/22/takto-vyrastie-novy-stadion|title=Takto vyrastie nový štadión|date=2016-04-22|website=Takto vyrastie nový štadión {{!}} FC DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda|access-date=2016-05-02}} ===Owners=== DAC Arenahttp://sport.sme.sk/c/20386172/v-dunajskej-strede-vyrastie-futbalova-katedrala.html?ref=trz is owned by EHCS Group (51.9%), city of [[Dunajská Streda]] (25.6%) and [[MOL Group|MOL]] (22.5%) ===Name=== MOL Arena is the name of the stadium from season [[2017–18 Slovak First Football League|2017-18]]https://sport.aktuality.sk/c/284000/stadion-v-dunajskej-strede-ponesie-nove-meno/ because [[MOL Group]] is main partner of stadium. ===Cost=== The cost of the reconstruction is €22 million.http://www.profutbal.sk/ligy/svk1/clanok216116-DAC_konecne_vo_svojom_Vilagi_Chceme_svetovu_uroven_video.htm First phase cost €11 million, [[Fico's Second Cabinet|Slovak government]] provided €2.4 million of the cost. City of [[Dunajská Streda]] provided €2 million, [[MOL Group|MOL]] provided €2 million. ==International matches== DAC Aréna has hosted one friendly match of the [[Slovakia national football team]]. {{footballbox_collapsible |date = 30 March 1993 |time = |round = International Friendly |team1 = {{fb|SVK}} |goals1=[[Ľubomír Luhový]] {{goal|27}}
[[Pavol Diňa]] {{goal|55}} (penalty) |score = 2-2 |report = [http://www.11v11.com/matches/slovakia-v-lithuania-30-march-1993-245589/] |team2 = {{fb|LTU}} |goals2= [[Ricardas Zdancius]] {{goal|41}},{{goal|71}} |stadium=[[Mestský štadión Dunajská Streda]] |location=[[Dunajská Streda]], [[Slovakia]] |attendance=2,000 |referee=Karol Ihring |result = D |stack= }} ==Image gallery== [[File:DAC Arena.png|250px]] ==External links== *[http://stadiumdb.com/stadiums/svk/mestsky_stadion_dunajska_streda Stadium Database Article] *[http://www.fotbalovestadiony.cz/mestsky-stadion-dunajska-streda Football stadiums profile] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Slovakia-sports-venue-stub}} {{Slovak Super Liga stadiumlist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dac Stadion}} [[Category:Football venues in Slovakia]] [[Category:FK DAC 1904 Dunajská Streda|Stadium]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Trnava Region]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1953]]
